creator: vincent.hardy@sun.com
text:
Issues reported by Chris Lilley:

Hello batik-users,

  In the preferences, the language code for Indonesian is given as
  'in'. This is incorrect, it is 'id'.

  There is no language code 'in'
  
  http://lcweb.loc.gov/standards/iso639-2/langcodes.html#ij
  
  This results in incorrect rendering for content that uses
  system-language to give Indonesian-localized content.
  
======================================================================

Hello batik-users,

  The language code iu for Inuktitut is missing from Batik
  preferences. While not a bug, it sure would make testing and demos
  easier if it were there ;-)
  
  http://lcweb.loc.gov/standards/iso639-2/langcodes.html#ij

  The flag, since you use flags as icons for languages, may be
  obtained from
  http://www.nunavut.com/misc/inuktitut/flag.html

=========================================================================

  Hmm, there seems to be a number of errors in these mappings:

ik = Inupiak not Inupiaq (perhaps this is just spelling?)
jv vs jw for Javanese - (Important one for a Java App ehh? :)

=========================================================================

Yes but as you could intuit from my two recent mails, I only got up
to "I" on my testing so far ;-)

Also, I don't have test examples for all of the languages, just 666 or
so of them. So, there may be errors before I for languages I didn't
test.


TED>    I'm guessing there must be others these are just the one's I
TED> noticed quickly.  Vincent, Thierry any idea where this list came from
TED> originally?

I should point out that the URL I gave is the official ISO 639
registration authority, in other words whatever is on that page is the
official ISO definition and, as new language codes get added over
time, their apearance on that page makes them official.

TED>    I'm guessing there must be others these are just the one's I
TED> noticed quickly.  Vincent, Thierry any idea where this list came from

Another mistake (which might help date the original list used by
Batik) sh is given as Serbo-Croatian.

There is (no longer) such a code (a problem for historical documents
but there we are) instead Serbian is sr.

Croatian is hr (and is already in Batik).

Hello batik-users,

  Language code te (Telugu) is mis-spelled Tegulu in the preferences.
  This has no effect on correct rendering and is merely an aesthetic
  glitch/spelling error.

  http://lcweb.loc.gov/standards/iso639-2/langcodes.html#st
